body:
Thanks for the report. Something strange is going on, since this doesn't error for 

```python

In [101]: s = dd.from_pandas(pd.Series([], dtype='int', name='A'), 2)

In [102]: s.values.compute()
Out[102]: array([], dtype=int64)
```

Are you interested in looking further @lr4d?

It appears to be specfically related to when a reduction is performed, as `ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"] + 1, meta=meta).values.compute()` also works.

>Are you interested in looking further @lr4d?

I am, but I don't have too much spare time atm. I may try looking into this next Friday

Digging a bit further today, it seems like the issue lies in `map_partititions`. 

If calling `ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(), meta=meta)`, `map_partitions` returns `new_dd_object(graph, name, meta, divisions)`. The `graph` would return a `np.int` but since `meta=pd.Series`, this statement returns a Series.

However, when calling `ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(), meta=meta).values`, `map_partitions` is called only once, and, crucially, `new_dd_object(graph, name, meta, divisions)` is not called on the intermediary output (the `np.int` that was converted to a Series in the previous scenario) . Then, `values` is called on a `np.int` object, which raises the exception provided in the original post.


```python
dask.compute(ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(), meta=meta).values, optimize_graph=False, scheduler="synchronous")
> /Users/xrzq/public_workspace/dask/dask/dataframe/core.py(4833)map_partitions()
   4832 
-> 4833     return new_dd_object(graph, name, meta, divisions)
   4834 
ipdb> >? graph.layers
{'values-538ebcb3e2ab5e808abd46b82347d794': <dask.blockwise.Blockwise object at 0x10c291a58>, 'lambda-ed40d14d6a25e71b80d255bfff06330a': <dask.blockwise.Blockwise object at 0x1115357f0>, 'from_pandas-75805870329f1928e094729c0f089a96': {('from_pandas-75805870329f1928e094729c0f089a96', 0):    A
0  1
1  2}}
```

Any tips on how to move forward? @TomAugspurger

Not off the top of my head, sorry.

On Fri, Sep 6, 2019 at 11:20 AM Lucas Rademaker <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Digging a bit further today, it seems like the issue lies in
> map_partititions.
>
> If calling ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(), meta=meta),
> map_partitions returns new_dd_object(graph, name, meta, divisions). The
> graph would return a np.int but since meta=pd.Series, this statement
> returns a Series.
>
> However, when calling ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(),
> meta=meta).values, map_partitions is called only once, and, crucially, new_dd_object(graph,
> name, meta, divisions) is not called on the intermediary output (the
> np.int that was converted to a Series in the previous scenario) . Then,
> values is called on a np.int object, which raises the exception provided
> in the original post.
>
> dask.compute(ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df["A"].sum(), meta=meta).values, optimize_graph=False, scheduler="synchronous")> /Users/xrzq/public_workspace/dask/dask/dataframe/core.py(4833)map_partitions()
>    4832 -> 4833     return new_dd_object(graph, name, meta, divisions)
>    4834
> ipdb> >? graph.layers
> {'values-538ebcb3e2ab5e808abd46b82347d794': <dask.blockwise.Blockwise object at 0x10c291a58>, 'lambda-ed40d14d6a25e71b80d255bfff06330a': <dask.blockwise.Blockwise object at 0x1115357f0>, 'from_pandas-75805870329f1928e094729c0f089a96': {('from_pandas-75805870329f1928e094729c0f089a96', 0):    A0  11  2}}
>
> Any tips on how to move forward? @TomAugspurger
> <https://github.com/TomAugspurger>
>

> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/dask/dask/issues/5263?email_source=notifications&email_token=AAKAOIRHRT3GASNP7TRLKDTQIJ7NNA5CNFSM4ILC5KIKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOD6DK2YA#issuecomment-528919904>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAKAOIXTQVVQEWGYK2PWQGTQIJ7NNANCNFSM4ILC5KIA>

>

I think `map_partitions` assumes that the resulting computation still produces a dataframe-like or series-like object.  From the end of the doc string:

> Also note that the index and divisions are assumed to remain unchanged.
If the function you're mapping changes the index/divisions, you'll need
to clear them afterwards:

The operation, `df['A'].sum()` produces an integer which has no index.  What happens to work is, if instead you call with a list of columns the reduction should return a series and not an integer.

> ddf.map_partitions(lambda df: df[["A"]].sum(), meta=meta).values.compute()
